Crimes.Crime_Type: Human Rights Violations and Serious International Law Offenses
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Involved: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA), Charter of Rights and Freedoms
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Alleged collusion between Canada and U.S. to use deportation as disguised extradition
Crimes.Legal_Framework: IRPA, Charter of Rights and Freedoms, case law on extradition and deportation
Crimes.Evidence_Requirement: Heavy proof required to establish improper purpose or disguised extradition
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: No evidence of disguised extradition or irreparable harm
Crimes.Government_Body_or_Authority: Immigration Division of the Immigration and Refugee Board
Crimes.Exemptions_or_Defenses_Cited: Deportation for public good is legitimate
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Lack of direct evidence of collusion
Crimes.Individual_Status_or_Claim: Lebanese citizen facing U.S. criminal charges
Crimes.Temporal_Context: Present deportation proceedings following prior U.S. criminal accusations
Crimes.Personal_Data_Implicated: Criminal history, immigration status, travel records
Crimes.Legal_Statute: Section 34(1) IRPA (inadmissibility on grounds of serious criminality)
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Whether deportation constitutes de facto extradition without safeguards
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Burden on applicant to show bad faith or improper purpose
Crimes.Protection_Claim: Right to fair process under Charter
Crimes.State_Protection_Assessment: Deemed adequate; no risk from lawful deportation
Crimes.Credibility: Not challenged on facts but claim unsubstantiated
Crimes.Targeted_Group: Foreign nationals with foreign criminal convictions
Crimes.State_Protection_Adequacy: Found adequate under existing legal framework
Crimes.Claimant_Status: Non-citizen lawfully present but alleged inadmissible
Crimes.Legal_Basis: Public interest in removing individuals not conducive to national good
Crimes.Victim_Basis: Alleged violation of procedural fairness and right against self-incrimination

Crimes.Crime_Name: Inadmissibility due to foreign criminal offences
Crimes.Crime_Type: Human Rights Violations and Serious International Law Offenses
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Judicial review of admissibility hearing fairness
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Involved: IRPA, Charter of Rights and Freedoms
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Bias by Board member, risk of self-incrimination, disguised extradition
Crimes.Legal_Framework: IRPA, Charter s. 7, administrative law principles
Crimes.Evidence_Requirement: Demonstration of actual bias or procedural unfairness
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: No evidence of bias or disguised extradition
Crimes.Exemptions_or_Defenses_Cited: Procedural safeguards in place, no compulsion yet imposed
Crimes.Individual_Status_or_Claim: Lebanese citizen with U.S. fraud convictions
Crimes.Legal_Statute: IRPA s. 36(2)(a) – inadmissibility for foreign criminality
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Objective appearance of bias, procedural fairness
Crimes.Protection_Claim: Charter protection against self-incrimination and fair hearing
Crimes.State_Protection_Assessment: Available through judicial review and procedural rights
Crimes.State_Protection_Adequacy: Adequate due to independent review mechanisms
Crimes.Risk_Nature: Legal and personal consequences of removal
Crimes.Victim_Basis: Alleged denial of fair process and Charter rights

Crimes.Crime_Name: Compelling testimony concerns under Charter rights
Crimes.Crime_Type: Human Rights Violations and Serious International Law Offenses
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Pre-hearing challenge to potential compulsion of testimony
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Involved: Charter of Rights and Freedoms s. 7, IRPA
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Potential self-incrimination in U.S. proceedings if compelled to testify
Crimes.Remedy_Requested: Stay of proceedings to prevent Charter breach
Crimes.Evidence_Requirement: Actual decision to compel testimony needed
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: No current compulsion; issue not ripe for review
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Hypothetical scenario based on applicant’s fears
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Whether compulsion would violate right against self-incrimination
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Section 7 Charter protection applies only when compulsion occurs
Crimes.State_Protection_Assessment: Sufficient safeguards exist if compulsion arises
Crimes.Risk_Factor: Use of testimony in future U.S. prosecution
Crimes.State_Protection_Adequacy: Process allows for objection at time of compulsion
Crimes.Claimant_Status: Foreign national under investigation for inadmissibility
Crimes.Legal_Basis: Absence of explicit compulsion in IRPA

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Immigration inadmissibility based on foreign conviction for fraud
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Use of prior fraud conviction as basis for inadmissibility
Crimes.Procedural_Context: Judicial review of pending admissibility process
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Conviction for fraud in the United States
Crimes.Evaluation_Standard: Seriousness of offense, proportionality, public interest
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Nature and gravity of fraud conviction
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Reasonableness of proceeding despite self-incrimination fear
Crimes.Decision_Review_Issue: Whether proceeding violates Charter or constitutes disguised extradition
Crimes.Outcome_of_Review: No merit in claims of Charter breach or disguised extradition
Crimes.Cause_of_Refusal: Conviction for serious non-violent crime abroad
Crimes.Procedural_Fairness: Opportunity to present case at hearing
